[[File:Conjoined trees at Bold Moon in Fall.jpg|right|210px|thumb|Conjoined trees at Bold Moon Farm in rural Guilford County, North Carolina.]] {{Radical feminism sidebar|expanded=Actions and ideas}}{{LGBT sidebar}}{{Sociology}}
'''Womyn's land''' (also called '''lesbian land''',<ref name="Cheney">{{Cite book|editor-last=Cheney|editor-first=Joyce|title=Lesbian Land|publisher=Word Weavers|year=1985|isbn=978-0961560508}}</ref> '''wimmin's land''', '''landdyke communities''', or '''women's land'''<ref name="Levy" />) is a term which refers to [[Intentional community|intentional communities]] organized by [[Womyn-born womyn|women]] to empower [[female|women]].<ref name="Levy">{{Cite web|last=Levy|first=Ariel|title=Lesbian Nation|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2009/03/02/lesbian-nation|work=[[The New Yorker]]|date=March 2, 2009|accessdate=April 26, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Ellison|first1=Kate|title=Lesbian Intentional Community: "Yer not from around here, are ya?"|url=https://www.ic.org/wiki/lesbian-intentional-community-yer-around-ya/|website=[[Fellowship for Intentional Community]]|date=September 30, 2013|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref> These [[Community|communities]] mainly exist in rural areas where land is utilized to establish [[Counterculture|counter-cultural]], women-centered space, often without the presence of [[male]]s.<ref name="Levy" /> The first known women's land community in the US was the Sanctificationists, later known as the Woman's Commonwealth, which was established in Texas in the late 1870s to 1880s.<ref name="Sanctified">{{cite book|last1=Lufburrow|first1=Debra |title=Set Apart: The Sanctified Sisters|date=2001|publisher=Booklocker.com|isbn=978-1929072712}}</ref> In the 1970s, women's land-based communities that explicitly welcomed lesbians were established in the US, Australia, New Zealand, and western Europe.<ref name="Cheney" /> Many still exist today.<ref name="Kershaw">{{Cite news|last1=Kershaw|first1=Sarah|title=My Sister's Keeper|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/01/fashion/01womyn.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 30, 2009|accessdate=April 27, 2017}}</ref> Womyn's land-based communities and residents are loosely networked through social media; print publications such as newsletters; Maize: A Lesbian Country Magazine;<ref>{{cite web|title=Maize, A Lesbian Country Magazine|url=http://womanearthandspirit.org|publisher=Woman, Earth & Spirit, Inc.|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Maize|url=http://www.lesbianpoetryarchive.org/Maize|accessdate=13 June 2018|via=Lesbian Poetry Archive}}</ref> Lesbian Natural Resources, a not-for-profit organization that offers grants and resources; and regional and local gatherings to form a [[social movement]] variously called the lesbian land movement, womyn's land movement, and/or landdyke movement.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Waldner|editor1-first=Lisa K.|editor2-last=Dobratz|editor2-first=Betty A.|editor3-last=Buzzell|editor3-first=Tim|title=Politics of Change: Sexuality, Gender and Aging (Research in Political Sociology, Volume 13)|date=2004|publisher=[[Emerald Group Publishing]]|pages=13–46|chapter=Rivers of ideas, participants, and praxis: the benefits and challenges of confluence in the Landdyke movement (by Sine Anahita)|isbn=978-0762309917 }}</ref>
Some womyn's lands practice [[Separatist feminism|lesbian separatism]], an idea which emerged as a result of the [[Radical feminism|Radical Feminist]] movement in the late 1960s.<ref name="Bess">{{cite web|last=Bess|first=Gabby|title=No Man's Land: How to Build a Feminist Utopia|url=https://broadly.vice.com/en_us/article/no-mans-land-how-to-build-a-feminist-utopia|website=Broadly|date=October 13, 2015|accessdate=April 26, 2017}}</ref> Lesbian separatism is based on the idea that women must exist separately from men, socially and politically, in order to achieve a true [[Feminism|feminist]] or [[lesbian utopia]].<ref name="Shugar1">{{Cite book|last=Shugar|first=Dana R.|title=Separatism and Women's Community|publisher=[[University of Nebraska Press]]|year=1995|pages=xi–13|isbn=978-0803242449}}</ref> The radical feminist group [[Cell 16]] is often credited for establishing the base of ideas that define lesbian separatism.<ref name="Bess" /> These [[Separatism|separatist]] communities exist as a way for women to achieve [[Women's liberation|female liberation]] by separating themselves from mainstream [[patriarchal society]].<ref name="Shugar1" /> Men are not allowed to live in, or enter these communities.<ref name="Kershaw" /> Some communities ban male infants and/or male relatives.<ref name="Kershaw" />
Womyn's lands, as well as lesbian separatism, have generated a wide range of criticisms. These criticism center around, but are not limited to, the lack of acceptance by many residents of [[Bisexuality|bisexual]] and [[Heterosexuality|heterosexual]] women; the exclusion of [[Trans woman|transgender]] and [[transsexual]] women for not being [[Biological sex|biological]] females;<ref name="Browne" /><ref name="Kershaw" /> ideological conflicts with local communities that include violence and threats of violence targeting residents of womyn's land;<ref name="Lynch" /><ref name="Reno" /> and local community concerns about social change, e.g. rising divorce rates<ref name="Sokolow" /> and expanded lesbian visibility.<ref name="Lynch" /><ref name="Greene">{{Cite journal|last=Greene|first=Kate|date=2003|title=Fear and Loathing in Mississippi: The Attack on Camp Sister Spirit|journal=[[Journal of Lesbian Studies]]|volume=7|issue=2|pages=85–106|issn=1089-4160}}</ref> Examples of present-day womyn's lands include Hawk Hill Community Land Trust, HOWL, Susan B. Anthony Memorial Unrest Home (SUBAMUH) and Sugar Loaf Women's Village.<ref name="Vice">{{cite web|last1=Conti|first1=Allie|title=Who's Killing the Women's Land Movement?|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/jpmdky/whos-killing-the-womens-land-movement|website=[[Vice Media|Vice]]|date=December 18, 2016|accessdate=April 27, 2017}}</ref> Today, these communities are facing decline as the founders age, as well as the struggle to connect with younger generations of women.<ref name="Kershaw" />
== Background history == === Sanctificationists a.k.a. Woman's Commonwealth === Founded in the late 1870s to early 1880s, the Sanctificationists, later known as the Woman's Commonwealth, were a women's land-based commune first established in Belton, Texas.<ref name="Sanctified" /> The community was originally established by Martha McWhirter and her women's bible study group on land that was inherited when the women's husbands died or quit the home. Residents of the commune were women and their dependent children; many of the women fled abusive homes to join the community. The Sisters embraced first wave feminist ideologies, and sought spiritual, economic, and social equality for women.<ref name="Kitch">{{cite journal|last1=Kitch|first1=Sally|title=The Woman's Commonwealth: Celibacy and Women's Rights|journal=[[Communities (magazine)|Communities]]|date=Spring 1994|issue=82|pages=40–44}}</ref> To that end, they practiced celibacy as a way to liberate women from the spiritual degradation of heterosexual intercourse, the oppressive needs of children and child rearing, and male violence.<ref name="Kitch" /> The Sanctificationists were economically successful; they ran several boarding houses, two hotels, formed holding companies to manage their properties, and operated two farms to provide food for their multiple dining rooms. At one point, there were between 42 and 50 women members on record,<ref name="Kitch" /><ref name="Sanctified" /> including at least one African American woman who is thought to be a former slave.<ref name="Sanctified" /> In 1899, the entire commune moved to Washington, DC where they opened boarding houses, a hotel, and participated in urban feminist organizations.<ref name="Kitch" /><ref name="Sokolow">{{cite journal|last1=Sokolow|first1=Jayme A.|last2=Lamanna|first2=Mary Ann|title=Women and Utopia: The Woman's Commonwealth of Belton, Texas|jstor=30236969|journal=The Southwestern Historical Quarterly|date=April 1984|volume=87|issue=4|pages=371–392|oclc=01766223}}</ref> McWhirter died in 1904, and the commune began a slow decline. In 1917, there were six remaining members who purchased a farm in rural Maryland to provide food for their urban dining halls, and to provide a pastoral retreat for themselves in a rural landscape. The last member of the commune died in 1983 at the age of 101.<ref name="Sokolow" />
A brief article published in the [[List of lesbian periodicals in the United States|lesbian separatist periodical]], ''Austindyke (''alternately spelled as ''Austin Dyke),'' in 1979 and then reprinted in ''Sisters United'' in 1980 described the Woman's Commonwealth as a forerunner of the lesbian land movement.<ref>Peticolas, Anne. (1980). "Reclaiming hystory: The Belton Sanctificationists." ''Sisters United'' 20(6): 13.</ref>{{Full citation needed|date=June 2018}} It is unclear whether the Sanctificationists influenced the movement that flourished in the 1970s and 1980s.<ref name="Anahita">{{cite journal|last1=Anahita|first1=Sine|title=Nestled into Niches: Prefigurative Communities on Lesbian Land|journal=[[Journal of Homosexuality]]|date=2009|volume=56|issue=6|pages=719–737|issn=0091-8369|doi=10.1080/00918360903054186|pmid=19657932}}</ref>
=== Radical feminism === [[Radical feminism]] advocates for the elimination of female [[oppression]] through a call towards social and political transformation of patriarchal society.<ref name="Lewis">{{cite web|last1=Lewis|first1=Jone Johnson|title=What Is Radical Feminism?|url=https://www.thoughtco.com/what-is-radical-feminism-3528997|website=[[ThoughtCo]]|date=June 6, 2005|accessdate=April 27, 2017}} (Updated August 15, 2017)</ref> Radical feminism grew out of other radical movements during the 1960s such as the [[Anti-war movement|Anti-War Movement]].<ref name="Lewis" /> Women who took part in these radical movements felt under-represented in comparison to the men, which contributed to the formation of [[second-wave feminism]] and radical feminism.<ref name="Lewis" />
[[Radical feminism#Theory and ideology|Radical feminist ideology]] is different from [[Feminist movements and ideologies#Mainstream feminism|mainstream]] or [[liberal feminism]] because it believes that [[women's liberation]] can only be achieved through the re-ordering of patriarchal society, while mainstream/liberal feminism seeks equality within the current system in place.<ref name="Echols">{{Cite book|last=Echols|first=Alice|title=Daring To Be Bad: Radical Feminism in America 1967-1975|publisher=[[University of Minnesota Press]]|year=1989|pages=6–7|isbn=978-0816617869}}</ref> Radical feminism also focuses on [[sex]] as the root of female oppression, as opposed to [[social class]] and/or [[race (human categorization)|race]].<ref name="Echols" /> Notable radical feminist groups and organizations include [[Cell 16]], [[Redstockings]], The Radical Feminists #28 and [[The Furies Collective]].<ref name="Napikoski">{{cite web|last1=Napikoski|first1=Linda|title=Redstockings Radical Feminist Group|url=https://www.thoughtco.com/redstockings-womens-liberation-group-3528981|website=[[ThoughtCo]]|date=December 30, 2009|accessdate=April 28, 2017}} (Updated May 4, 2017)</ref><ref name="Bess" /><ref name="Thomas">{{Cite news|last=Thomas|first=June|title=The National Register of Historic Places Adds Its First Lesbian Landmark|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/outward/2016/05/06/furies_collective_joins_national_register_of_historic_places.html|date=May 6, 2016|website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=April 28, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Shugar1"/>
=== Lesbian separatism and separatist spaces === Lesbian separatism is rooted in the idea that women should and must exist separately from men in order to achieve a true feminist [[utopia]].<ref name="Shugar1" /> Lesbian separatist ideology has changed over time as the Radical Feminist Movement continued in its development. In the earlier stages of lesbian separatism the term "lesbian separatist" was considered synonymous to the term "radical feminist".<ref name="Shugar1" /> However, as each group developed distinct ideologies, tension formed between radical feminists and lesbian separatists.<ref name="Shugar1" /> Lesbian separatists used the separatist ideology as a way to "test one's feminist commitment",<ref name="Shugar1" /> which resulted in a divide.
An increase in [[lesbian feminism]] essays and papers centered around the subject of lesbian separatism, influenced and shaped lesbian separatist ideology as well.<ref name="Shugar1" /> Influential works which helped shape lesbian separatism included ''Lesbian Separatism: Amazon Analysis,'' the ''Collective Lesbian International Terrorists Papers,'' and [[Cell 16]]'s ''No More Fun and Games: A Journal of Female Liberation''.<ref>{{cite journal|editor1-last=Dunbar|editor1-first=Roxanne|editor2-last=Densmore|editor2-first=Dana|editor3-last=Warrior|editor3-first=Betsy |title=No More Fun and Games: a Journal of Female Liberation|url=https://dukelibraries.contentdm.oclc.org/digital/collection/p15957coll6/id/132/rec/1|date=February 1969|volume=1|issue=2|publisher=[[Cell 16]]|via=[[Duke University Libraries]]}} ("No. 1" in Duke Library title is incorrect.)</ref><ref name="Shugar1" />
Lesbian separatism is not only practiced and utilized in communal areas such as womyn's lands; it is also practiced in separatist events and [[women-only space]]s. One example of a feminist separatist event (the invited participants were womyn-born-womyn, girls of all ages, boys 10 and under) is the [[Michigan Womyn's Music Festival]].<ref name="Browne">{{cite journal|last1=Browne|first1=Kath|title=Womyn's Separatist Spaces: Rethinking Spaces of Difference and Exclusion|jstor=40270736|journal=Transactions of the Institute of British Geographers|date=October 2009|volume=34|issue=4|pages=541–556|issn=0020-2754}}</ref> This [[music festival]] was held in [[Michigan]] every year from 1976 to 2015.<ref name="Blade">{{cite web|last1=King|first1=Lori|title=Womyn's Rite: Annual Michigan Fest roared for 40 years|url=http://www.toledoblade.com/Music-Theater-Dance/2015/08/16/Womyn-s-Rite-Annual-Michigan-Fest-roared-for-40-years.html|website=[[The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)|The Blade]]|date=August 16, 2015|accessdate=June 29, 2017}}</ref> It was created by women for the purpose of establishing an annual [[safe space|safe]], [[social space]] dedicated for [[Lesbianism|lesbians]] and females alike.<ref name="Blade" /><ref name="Browne" /> The Michigan Womyn's Music Festival embraced a separatist ideology by not permitting men, male children, or transgender women to participate in the festival.<ref name="Browne" />
==== Significance to feminist thought and woman-based communities ==== Feminist ideology maintains that the patriarchal institutions and social norms which make up [[society]] are the source of [[Sexism|female oppression]].<ref name="Shugar2">{{Cite book|last=Shugar|first=Dana R.|title=Separatism and Women's Community|publisher=[[University of Nebraska Press]]|year=1995|page=42|isbn=978-0803242449}}</ref> Lesbian separatist ideology recognizes the [[oppression]] which results from patriarchal society, however, it asserts that the root of oppression derives from men themselves, individually and as a group.<ref name="Shugar2" /> Unlike [[feminism]], lesbian separatism views men as the main source of their oppression.<ref name="Frye">{{cite book|last1=Frye|first1=Marilyn|title=Politics of Reality: Essays in Feminist Theory|date=1983|publisher=[[Crossing Press]]|edition=1st|chapter="Some Reflections on Separatism and Power"|isbn=978-0895940995}}</ref> Through this ideology, many lesbian separatists consider men as the sole perpetrators of adverse [[Economic inequality|economic]], societal, and [[Culture|cultural]] issues which affect them.<ref name="Shugar2" /> As a result, lesbian separatists sought to construct autonomous Womyn's land communities where they could live [[Sex segregation|segregated]] from men entirely.<ref name="Shugar2" />
== Criticisms == Womyn's land communities have been targeted for criticism. In the 1880s, the citizens of Belton, Texas blamed the Sanctificationists (also known as the Woman's Commonwealth) for rising separation and divorce rates, and of undermining the meaning of marriage through their practice of celibacy.<ref name="Sokolow" /><ref name="KitchStrange">{{cite book|last1=Kitch|first1=Sally L.|title=This Strange Society of Women: Reading the Letters and Lives of the Women's Commonwealth|date=1992|publisher=[[Ohio State University Press]]|edition=1st|isbn=978-0814205792}}</ref>
[[File:FEMA - 19717 - Photograph by Patsy Lynch taken on 11-27-2005 in Mississippi.jpg|left|200px|thumb|alt=Photograph of Camp Sister Spirit resident donating supplies to church community.|Residents of Camp Sister Spirit are active in their local community, donating food, clothing, and other supplies.]]
In 1993, residents of Camp Sister Spirit, located in rural [[Ovett, Mississippi]], were criticized by local community leaders including Southern Baptist ministers, Jones County Deputy Sheriff Myron Holifield, and US Representative Michael Parker, who held well-attended town hall meetings and a fundraiser to raise money to force the camp to close.<ref name="Lynch">{{Cite journal|last=Lynch|first=Thomas P.|date=Winter 1995|title=Camp Sister Spirit: A retreat under siege|journal=Mediation Quarterly|volume=13|issue=2|pages=151–163|issn=1536-5581|doi=10.1002/crq.3900130208}}</ref><ref name="Reno">{{Cite news|title=Reno Sends Mediators To Mississippi As Lesbian-Run Camp Divides Town|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1994/02/19/reno-sends-mediators-to-mississippi-as-lesbian-run-camp-divides-town/761c8412-5a08-499b-9eab-7de04dd5c090/|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=February 19, 1994|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref> The Reverend John S. Allen, who was a pastor in [[Richton, Mississippi|Richton]], a town close to Ovett, preached and wrote against Camp Sister Spirit citing biblical concerns about homosexuality.<ref name="Lynch" /><ref name="Greene" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Allen|first1=John S.|title=The Homosexual Agenda and the Church: Silence Equals Consent|work=The Baptist Record|publisher=Mississippi Baptist Convention Board|date=January 6, 1994}}</ref> Residents of the land received bomb threats, hate mail, vandalism, death threats by phone, and other acts of terrorism.<ref>{{cite web|title=LGBT History: The Hensons and Camp Sister Spirit|url=http://unityms.org/news/history-the-hensons-and-camp-sister-spirt.html|website=Unity Mississippi|date=November 16, 2014|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="Reno" /><ref name="Greene" /> Local law enforcement officials downplayed the threats against Camp Sister Spirit and failed to adequately investigate.<ref name="Lynch" /> In 1994, then Attorney General [[Janet Reno]] asked the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) to investigate the potential for violence against Camp Sister Spirit, and later sent federal [[Mediation|mediators]] to attempt resolution.<ref name="Lynch" /><ref name="Reno" /><ref name="Greene" /> The opponents of Camp Sister Spirit refused to participate in mediation; a group filed one lawsuit against Reno, and another against Camp Sister Spirit.<ref name="Lynch" /> The conflict also appeared on talk shows and in a Congressional hearing with both sides arguing their different views.<ref name="Lynch" /><ref name="Greene" />
Lesbian separatist communities have been criticized for exclusionary policies towards [[Trans woman|transgender]], [[transsexual]], [[Bisexuality|bisexual]], and [[Heterosexuality|heterosexual]] women.<ref name="Browne" /><ref name="Kershaw" /> Usually, [[homosexual]] females are the only persons permitted to be a member of these communities.<ref name="Kershaw" /> Some womyn's lands have also been criticized for excluding [[women of color]] and [[working class]] lesbians.<ref name="Shugar3">{{Cite book|last=Shugar|first=Dana R.|title=Separatism and Women's Community|publisher=[[University of Nebraska Press]]|year=1995|pages=xi–50|isbn=978-0803242449}}</ref> In the past, lesbian separatist communities were also accused of being a privilege offered solely to the few who could afford the closed-off [[Lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]].<ref name="Shugar3" />
The [[Michigan Womyn's Music Festival]] was an annual women's music festival held on privately-owned womyn's land near Hart, Michigan, that ran from 1976 through 2015.<ref name="Ring">{{Cite news|last=Ring|first=Trudy|title=This Year's Michigan Womyn's Music Festival Will Be the Last|url=https://www.advocate.com/michfest/2015/04/21/years-michigan-womyns-music-festival-will-be-last|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|date=April 21, 2015|accessdate=10 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="dearsisters">{{cite web|last1=Michigan Womyn's Music Festival|title=Dear Sisters, Amazon, Festival family|url=https://www.facebook.com/michfest/posts/10153186431364831|website=[[Facebook]]|date=April 21, 2015|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> Controversy over the festival's principle that only [[womyn-born-womyn]] could participate began in 1991 and continued until the final gathering.<ref name="Cogswell">{{Cite web|last=Cogswell|first=Kelly|title=Dyke-Baiting, Trans-Hating, and the MichFest Debacle|url=http://gaycitynews.nyc/dyke-baiting-trans-hating-michfest-debacle/|work=[[Gay City News]]|date=April 29, 2015|accessdate=10 June 2018}}</ref> Critics of MichFest included actress/comedian [[Lea DeLaria]], music performers the [[Indigo Girls]], poet [[Andrea Gibson]], trans activist/comedian Red Durkin; and musicians [[Antigone Rising]].<ref name="Heithmar">{{Cite news|last=Heithmar|first=Judy|title=Michfest is dying from bigotry|url=https://socialistworker.org/2014/09/10/michfest-is-dying-from-bigotry|work=[[Socialist Worker]]|date=September 10, 2014|accessdate=10 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="Ring" />

Anthony Womyn's Land Trust|url=https://subamuh.wordpress.com|website=SuBAMUH|accessdate=June 29, 2017}}</ref> * We'moon Land<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wemoonland.org/about/|title=About|last=|first=|date=|website=We'Moon Land|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 February 2018}}</ref> * WomanShare<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.applegater.org/pdf/2014/v07n03/v07n03p05.pdf|title=Local women's land celebrates 40 years|last=Miracle|first=Billie|date=Fall 2014|work=Applegater|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
== Novels about womyn's lands == Several novels have been published in English that have plots centering on womyn's land or female separatist communities<ref name="Shugar4">{{Cite book|last=Shugar|first=Dana R.|title=Separatism and Women's Community|publisher=[[University of Nebraska Press]]|year=1995|page=121|isbn=978-0803242449}}</ref> (see [[Single-gender world]]). These include:

Forrest]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Forrest|first1=Katherine V.|title=Daughters of a Coral Dawn|date=1984|publisher=[[Bella Books]]|url=https://www.bellabooks.com/product/9781594933042/|isbn=978-1594933042}}</ref> * ''The Demeter Flower'' by Rochelle Singer (a.k.a. Shelley Singer).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Singer|first1=Rochelle|title=The Demeter Flower|date=1980|publisher=[[St. Martin's Press]]|url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/1867684.The_Demeter_Flower|isbn=978-0312191955|via=[[Goodreads]]}}</ref> * ''[[Herland (novel)|Herland]]'' by [[Charlotte Perkins Gilman]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gilman|first1=Charlotte Perkins|title=Herland|date=1915|publisher=[[Pantheon Books]]|edition=1979|isbn=978-0-394-50388-2}}</ref>
